{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3356242,"name":"Nicholas Armstrong","username":"narmstro","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T13:58:39.053Z","cooked":"

The SparkMax’s kFF value is equivalent to kV determined by sysId and other sources… right?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-04-09T13:58:39.053Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":164,"readers_count":163,"score":77.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":461917,"topic_slug":"silly-sparkpidcontroller-question","display_username":"Nicholas Armstrong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48345,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/silly-sparkpidcontroller-question/461917/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3356487,"name":"Carlos Salazar","username":"StarbuckBarista","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/starbuckbarista/{size}/186251_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T16:32:21.952Z","cooked":"

Here’s a diagram from the SparkMAX Documentation that details precisely how their closed loop control method works. As you can see, the kFF value is multiplied with the set point. So, yes, it is comparable to WPILib’s kV value. However, if you plan on using values from WPILib tools, be cautious of what units the value is in.

So, if I am reading this right, with kD and kD at 0, there is only one kF that will work at a given RPM. correct?
So, what is the correct way to handle a shooter with variable RPM?

Well a combination of feedforward and feedback control is the most ideal way to control a velocity flywheel. There’s more information on the proper procedure from both the Phoenix 6 and WPILib documentation.

Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T20:13:52.842Z","cooked":"
StarbuckBarista:

it is comparable to WPILib’s kV value

Only for velocity setpoints, not for position setpoints. With that said, you can pass whatever feedforward voltage you want with REV’s arbFF feature (i.e., evaluate the feedforward in robot code, then send the value to the motor controller).

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-04-09T20:16:06.398Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":78,"readers_count":77,"score":40.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":461917,"topic_slug":"silly-sparkpidcontroller-question","display_username":"Tyler Veness","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16846,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend"},"post_url":"/t/silly-sparkpidcontroller-question/461917/7","custom_user_title":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3356837,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T21:08:12.325Z","cooked":"
billbo911:

variable RPM

kF is nearly a flat line. The velocity-voltage curves I’ve plotted are straight except for a little flattened at the extremes - a very long skinny italic ess S but not that curved - nearly straight. Plot yours and decide how you want to curve-fit it. Since kF that I’ve seen is typically less than the required voltage so the control has something to work with, the exact value isn’t critical. It’s usually easy to pick a value that well covers your velocity range. Some control schemes do need kF to get closer to the setpoint than others.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-04-09T21:08:12.325Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":64,"readers_count":63,"score":12.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":461917,"topic_slug":"silly-sparkpidcontroller-question","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/silly-sparkpidcontroller-question/461917/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3357227,"name":"Nicholas Armstrong","username":"narmstro","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T03:16:33.970Z","cooked":"

I do have to ask is there any issue with lining up the frequency of the robot code with the frequency of the SparkPIDController.
I know the SparkPIDController runs at 1ms and the RIO at 20ms. Would this be an instance to use a custom frequency on the RIO side in TimedRobot and if so how would that effect rio performance?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-04-10T03:16:33.970Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":55,"readers_count":54,"score":16.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":461917,"topic_slug":"silly-sparkpidcontroller-question","display_username":"Nicholas Armstrong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":16846,"username":"calcmogul","name":"Tyler Veness","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48345,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/silly-sparkpidcontroller-question/461917/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3357321,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T06:18:14.729Z","cooked":"
narmstro:

Would this be an instance to use a custom frequency on the RIO side in TimedRobot

The open-loop dynamics of your feedforward are unlikely to be fast enough for a faster update rate to have a noticeable effect, and your system is likely open-loop stable regardless. Also, 1 kHz is on the edge of current transients in the motor starting to matter, and pretty much no FRC mechanism needs that level of feedback control.

The main reason to use motor controller PID is determinism rather than update rate (no Java GC causing large delays).
